CP.title: Hello! My name is...
CP.content:
Hello! My name is...

Learn to greet people and introduce yourself in English. It's the first step to making new friends!

Here are some common phrases you can use:

  • Hello! / Hi!
  • My name is [your name].
  • What's your name?
  • Goodbye! / Bye bye!

Example:

"Hello! My name is Tom. What's your name?"

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Use "Hello!" or "Hi!" to greet someone.
  • Say "My name is [your name]" to introduce yourself.
  • Ask "What's your name?" to know someone else's name.
  • Use "Goodbye!" or "Bye bye!" when leaving.

CP.title: Counting from 1 to 10
CP.content:
Counting from 1 to 10

Let's learn to count from one to ten in English. Counting is very useful for everything!

Here are the numbers:

  • One
  • Two
  • Three
  • Four
  • Five
  • Six
  • Seven
  • Eight
  • Nine
  • Ten

Example:

"I have one apple."

"Let's count: one, two, three!"

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Practice saying each number clearly.
  • Try to count objects around you.

CP.title: Colors: Red, Blue, Yellow
CP.content:
Colors: Red, Blue, Yellow

Today, we're going to learn three basic colors in English. Colors help us describe the world around us!

The colors are:

  • Red
  • Blue
  • Yellow

Example:

"It's a red apple."

"I like the blue sky."

"The sun is yellow."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Red" for things like apples or fire trucks.
  • "Blue" for things like the sky or water.
  • "Yellow" for things like the sun or bananas.

CP.title: Animals: Cat, Dog, Bird
CP.content:
Animals: Cat, Dog, Bird

Let's learn the names of some common animals in English. Do you have a pet?

Here are the animals:

  • Cat
  • Dog
  • Bird

Example:

"I have a big dog."

"Look, a small cat is sleeping."

"A bird is singing in the tree."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Cat" is a small furry animal that says "meow".
  • "Dog" is a friendly animal that says "woof woof".
  • "Bird" is an animal that can fly.

CP.title: Body parts: Head, Shoulders, Knees, Toes
CP.content:
Body parts: Head, Shoulders, Knees, Toes

Let's discover parts of the body with a fun song! Knowing body parts is great for describing yourself and others.

Here are some body parts:

  • Head
  • Shoulders
  • Knees
  • Toes
  • Eyes
  • Ears
  • Mouth
  • Nose

Example (from the song):

"Head, shoulders, knees, and toes, knees and toes!"

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Head" is at the top.
  • "Eyes" are for seeing, "ears" are for hearing.
  • "Mouth" is for eating and talking, "nose" is for smelling.

CP.title: Simple instructions: Stand up! Sit down!
CP.content:
Simple instructions: Stand up! Sit down!

It's important to understand and follow basic classroom instructions. These help us know what to do!

Common instructions are:

  • Stand up!
  • Sit down!
  • Listen!
  • Look!

Example:

"Teacher says: Stand up!"

"Please sit down now."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Stand up!" means to get on your feet.
  • "Sit down!" means to take a seat.
  • "Listen!" means to pay attention with your ears.
  • "Look!" means to pay attention with your eyes.

CP.title: Simple questions: What's this? What's that?
CP.content:
Simple questions: What's this? What's that?

Learn to ask and answer simple questions about objects. This is how we learn new words!

Questions and answers:

  • What's this? It's a book.
  • What's that? It's a pencil.

Example:

"What's this? It's a ruler."

"What's that? It's a bag."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "What's this?" is for something close to you.
  • "What's that?" is for something further away.
  • Answer with "It's a [object name]."

CP.title: Family: Mum, Dad, Brother, Sister
CP.content:
Family: Mum, Dad, Brother, Sister

Let's learn to talk about your family members in English. Family is very important!

Key family words:

  • Mum
  • Dad
  • Brother
  • Sister

Example:

"This is my mum."

"I have a brother and a sister."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Mum" is another word for mother.
  • "Dad" is another word for father.
  • "Brother" is a boy sibling.
  • "Sister" is a girl sibling.

CE1.title: How are you? (Greetings and feelings)
CE1.content:
How are you? (Greetings and feelings)

After learning to introduce yourself, let's learn to ask and answer about feelings. This helps us share how we are doing!

Key phrases for feelings:

  • How are you?
  • I'm fine, thank you.
  • I'm happy / sad / hungry.

Example:

"How are you? I'm happy!"

"He is sad today."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "How are you?" is a common way to ask about someone's well-being.
  • Answer with "I'm fine, thank you." or describe your feeling (happy, sad, hungry).

CE1.title: Counting from 11 to 20
CE1.content:
Counting from 11 to 20

We've mastered 1 to 10! Now, let's continue counting in English from eleven to twenty.

Here are the numbers:

  • Eleven
  • Twelve
  • Thirteen
  • Fourteen
  • Fifteen
  • Sixteen
  • Seventeen
  • Eighteen
  • Nineteen
  • Twenty

Example:

"I have twelve pencils."

"Let's count: eighteen, nineteen, twenty!"

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Numbers from 13 to 19 end with "-teen".
  • "Twenty" is a new word to remember.

CE1.title: More colors: Green, Orange, Purple, Black, White
CE1.content:
More colors: Green, Orange, Purple, Black, White

We know red, blue, and yellow. Now, let's expand our color vocabulary with five new colors! The more colors you know, the better you can describe things!

The new colors are:

  • Green
  • Orange
  • Purple
  • Black
  • White

Example:

"The grass is green."

"I like orange juice."

"My cat is black and white."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Green" is the color of grass and leaves.
  • "Orange" is the color of oranges.
  • "Purple" is a mix of red and blue.
  • "Black" is the color of night, "White" is the color of snow.

CE1.title: Food: Apple, Banana, Pizza
CE1.content:
Food: Apple, Banana, Pizza

Let's learn to name some favorite foods in English! What do you like to eat?

Here are some food words:

  • Apple
  • Banana
  • Pizza
  • Juice

You can also express your likes and dislikes:

  • I like apples.
  • I don't like pizza.

Example:

"I want an apple."

"Do you like pizza?"

"I don't like bananas."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Use "I like [food]" to say what you enjoy.
  • Use "I don't like [food]" to say what you don't enjoy.

CE1.title: Family: Mum, Dad, Brother, Sister, Grandpa, Grandma
CE1.content:
Family: Mum, Dad, Brother, Sister, Grandpa, Grandma

We already know Mum, Dad, Brother, and Sister. Let's add two more important family members: your grandparents!

More family words:

  • Mum
  • Dad
  • Brother
  • Sister
  • Grandpa
  • Grandma

Example:

"This is my grandpa and my grandma."

"I love my family."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Grandpa" is short for grandfather.
  • "Grandma" is short for grandmother.
  • These are your parents' parents!

CE1.title: Classroom objects: Pencil, Book, Bag
CE1.content:
Classroom objects: Pencil, Book, Bag

Let's identify objects commonly found in the classroom. Knowing these words will help you talk about your school supplies!

Common classroom objects:

  • Pencil
  • Book
  • Bag
  • Table
  • Chair

Example:

"What is this? It's a pencil."

"Please put your book in your bag."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Pencil" is for writing.
  • "Book" is for reading.
  • "Bag" is for carrying your things.
  • "Table" and "chair" are for sitting and working.

CE2.title: What's the weather like? (Weather vocabulary)
CE2.content:
What's the weather like? (Weather vocabulary)

Let's learn to describe the weather in English. This is useful for talking about what you can do outside!

Key weather phrases:

  • What's the weather like?
  • It's sunny / rainy / cloudy / windy.

Example:

"What's the weather like today? It's sunny!"

"I need an umbrella because it's rainy."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Sunny" means the sun is shining.
  • "Rainy" means it's raining.
  • "Cloudy" means there are many clouds.
  • "Windy" means there is a lot of wind.

CE2.title: Numbers up to 100 (tens)
CE2.content:
Numbers up to 100 (tens)

We can count to twenty. Now, let's learn to count by tens up to one hundred! This will help us with bigger numbers.

Counting by tens:

  • Ten
  • Twenty
  • Thirty
  • Forty
  • Fifty
  • Sixty
  • Seventy
  • Eighty
  • Ninety
  • One hundred

You can also ask about age:

  • How old are you? I'm eight years old.

Example:

"I have thirty books."

"My grandpa is seventy years old."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Notice the "-ty" ending for most tens.
  • "One hundred" is the last big number in this group.

CE2.title: Animals and their sounds
CE2.content:
Animals and their sounds

Animals make different sounds! Let's learn to identify some animals and the sounds they make in English.

Animals and sounds:

  • A dog barks (woof woof).
  • A cat mews (meow).
  • A duck quacks (quack quack).

Example:

"The dog barks at the cat."

"Can you hear the duck quack?"

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Dogs say "woof woof".
  • Cats say "meow".
  • Ducks say "quack quack".

CE2.title: Clothes: T-shirt, Trousers, Shoes
CE2.content:
Clothes: T-shirt, Trousers, Shoes

Let's name basic clothing items in English. This is useful for talking about what you wear!

Common clothing items:

  • T-shirt
  • Trousers
  • Shoes
  • Dress
  • Coat

Example:

"I'm wearing a blue t-shirt and black trousers."

"She has new red shoes."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "T-shirt" is a shirt with short sleeves.
  • "Trousers" are long pants.
  • "Shoes" are for your feet.
  • "Dress" is for girls, "coat" is for cold weather.

CE2.title: Days of the week
CE2.content:
Days of the week

Let's learn the days of the week in order in English. Knowing the days helps us plan and talk about our schedule!

The days are:

  • Monday
  • Tuesday
  • Wednesday
  • Thursday
  • Friday
  • Saturday
  • Sunday

You can ask:

  • What day is it today?

Example:

"Today is Tuesday."

"I go to school from Monday to Friday."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • There are seven days in a week.
  • "Monday" is the first school day, "Sunday" is the last day of the weekend.

CE2.title: Prepositions of place: In, On, Under
CE2.content:
Prepositions of place: In, On, Under

Prepositions help us describe where objects are located. Let's learn three important ones: in, on, and under.

Key prepositions:

  • In: inside something.
  • On: on the surface of something.
  • Under: below something.

Example:

"The book is on the table."

"The cat is under the chair."

"The pencil is in the box."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "In" means inside.
  • "On" means on top of.
  • "Under" means beneath.

CM1.title: Daily routines (simple verbs: get up, eat, go to bed)
CM1.content:
Daily routines (simple verbs: get up, eat, go to bed)

Let's talk about everyday activities using simple present tense. These are things you do every day!

Common daily routine verbs:

  • I get up at 7 o'clock.
  • I eat breakfast.
  • I go to school.

Example:

"Every morning, I get up and then I eat breakfast."

"After school, I go to bed early."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Get up" means to wake up and get out of bed.
  • "Eat" means to consume food.
  • "Go to school" means to attend school.

CM1.title: Simple Present Tense (I like / I don't like)
CM1.content:
Simple Present Tense (I like / I don't like)

The simple present tense is used to express likes, dislikes, habits, and general truths. It's how we talk about what we usually do or feel.

To express likes and dislikes:

  • I like pizza.
  • I don't like fish.
  • Do you like chocolate? Yes, I do. / No, I don't.

Example:

"I like playing games."

"She doesn't like vegetables."

"Do you like reading? Yes, I do."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Use "I like..." for things you enjoy.
  • Use "I don't like..." for things you don't enjoy.
  • For questions, start with "Do you like...?"

CM1.title: Asking and answering simple questions (What is it? Where is it?)
CM1.content:
Asking and answering simple questions (What is it? Where is it?)

Practice forming and responding to basic questions. These questions help us get information about objects and their location.

Common simple questions:

  • What is it? It's a book.
  • Where is my bag? It's on the chair.

Example:

"What is it? It's a blue car."

"Where is the cat? It's under the bed."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "What is it?" asks for the identity of an object.
  • "Where is it?" asks for the location of an object.

CM1.title: Describing people (adjectives: tall, short, happy, sad)
CM1.content:
Describing people (adjectives: tall, short, happy, sad)

Use adjectives to describe physical appearance and feelings of people. Adjectives add more detail to our sentences!

Descriptive adjectives:

  • Tall
  • Short
  • Happy
  • Sad
  • Big
  • Small

Example:

"He is tall and she is short."

"The girl is happy, but the boy is sad."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Adjectives describe nouns (people, animals, things).
  • "Tall" and "short" describe height.
  • "Happy" and "sad" describe feelings.

CM1.title: Months of the year
CM1.content:
Months of the year

Let's learn the names of the months in English. Knowing the months helps us talk about birthdays, holidays, and seasons!

The months are:

  • January
  • February
  • March
  • April
  • May
  • June
  • July
  • August
  • September
  • October
  • November
  • December

Example:

"My birthday is in May."

"Christmas is in December."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • There are twelve months in a year.
  • Each month has a unique name.

CM1.title: Ordinal numbers: first, second, third
CM1.content:
Ordinal numbers: first, second, third

We know how to count, but sometimes we need to express order, like who came first in a race! These are called ordinal numbers.

Key ordinal numbers:

  • First
  • Second
  • Third
  • Fourth
  • Fifth
  • ... Tenth

Example:

"He was the first person to arrive."

"Today is the third of July."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Ordinal numbers tell us the position or order of something.
  • "First, second, third" are special; most others end in "-th".

CM1.title: Possessive adjectives (my, your, his, her)
CM1.content:
Possessive adjectives (my, your, his, her)

Possessive adjectives show who something belongs to. They tell us about possession!

Key possessive adjectives:

  • My: belongs to me.
  • Your: belongs to you.
  • His: belongs to him (a boy/man).
  • Her: belongs to her (a girl/woman).

Example:

"This is my book."

"That is your pen."

"This is his car."

"That is her doll."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Possessive adjectives always go before the noun.
  • They agree with the owner, not the thing owned.

CM2.title: Simple Past Tense (regular verbs)
CM2.content:
Simple Past Tense (regular verbs)

The Simple Past Tense tells us about actions that happened in the past and are now finished. For most regular verbs, we just add "-ed" to the end of the verb.

How to form the Simple Past with regular verbs:

  • Add "-ed" to the base form of the verb.
  • If the verb ends in "e", just add "-d".
  • If the verb ends in consonant + y, change "y" to "i" and add "-ed".

Examples:

  • Yesterday, I played football. (play + ed)
  • Last week, we walked to the park. (walk + ed)
  • Did you like the film? Yes, I did. / No, I didn't.

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Use the Simple Past for completed actions in the past.
  • Regular verbs usually end in "-ed" in the past tense.
  • "Did" is used for questions and negative sentences in the past.

CM2.title: Irregular verbs (go, have, be - simple past forms)
CM2.content:
Irregular verbs (go, have, be - simple past forms)

Not all verbs follow the "-ed" rule! Some common verbs have special, irregular forms in the simple past. You need to learn these by heart.

Simple past forms of key irregular verbs:

  • Go: I went to London. (Not "goed")
  • Have: She had a dog. (Not "haved")
  • Be: He was happy. They were sad. (Not "beed")

Example:

"Last summer, we went to the beach."

"Yesterday, I had a lot of homework."

"They were very tired after the game."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Irregular verbs don't follow the "-ed" rule for past tense.
  • Memorize the past forms of common irregular verbs like "go" (went), "have" (had), and "be" (was/were).

CM2.title: Present Continuous Tense (I am doing)
CM2.content:
Present Continuous Tense (I am doing)

The Present Continuous Tense describes actions happening right now, at this moment. It's formed with the verb "to be" (am, is, are) + the verb + "-ing".

How to form the Present Continuous:

  • Subject + am/is/are + verb + -ing.

Examples:

  • I am reading a book.
  • They are playing outside.
  • What are you doing?

Example:

"Look! The bird is singing."

"We are learning English right now."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Use "am/is/are" + "-ing" to talk about actions happening now.
  • "Am" for I, "is" for he/she/it, "are" for we/you/they.

CM2.title: Prepositions of time: at, in, on
CM2.content:
Prepositions of time: at, in, on

Just like prepositions of place, prepositions of time tell us when something happens. Let's learn to use "at," "in," and "on" correctly for time expressions.

Key prepositions of time:

  • At: for specific times of the day, night, and specific holidays.
  • In: for months, seasons, years, and parts of the day (morning, afternoon, evening).
  • On: for specific days of the week, dates, and special days (e.g., my birthday).

Examples:

  • at 3 o'clock, at night
  • in the morning, in July, in 2025
  • on Monday, on my birthday, on July 3rd

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "At" for precise times.
  • "In" for longer periods (months, years, seasons) and parts of the day.
  • "On" for specific days and dates.

CM2.title: Asking for and giving directions
CM2.content:
Asking for and giving directions

Learning how to ask for and give directions is very useful when you are in a new place. It helps you find your way around!

Key phrases for directions:

  • Excuse me, where is the station?
  • Go straight on.
  • Turn left / right.

Example:

"Excuse me, where is the library? Go straight on, then turn left at the traffic lights."

"To get to the shop, turn right after the bridge."

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • Start by saying "Excuse me" to be polite.
  • "Go straight on" means to continue without turning.
  • "Turn left/right" means to change direction.

CM2.title: Describing places (big, small, old, new)
CM2.content:
Describing places (big, small, old, new)

Use adjectives to describe different places. These words help us create a picture of a place in someone's mind.

Adjectives to describe places:

  • Big
  • Small
  • Old
  • New

You can also ask about existence:

  • Is there a park nearby? Yes, there is. / No, there isn't.

Example:

"London is a big city."

"This is an old house, but my car is new."

"Is there a small cafe around here?"

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Big" and "small" describe size.
  • "Old" and "new" describe age.
  • Use "Is there...?" to ask if something exists in a place.

CM2.title: Making suggestions (Let's... / Shall we...?)
CM2.content:
Making suggestions (Let's... / Shall we...?)

Learn how to propose activities to others. These phrases are useful when you want to do something together!

Phrases for making suggestions:

  • Let's go to the cinema! (More common and direct)
  • Shall we play a game? (More formal or polite)

Example:

"It's a nice day, let's go to the park!"

"I'm bored. Shall we watch a movie?"

Mémo : Ce qu'il faut retenir

  • "Let's" is a contraction of "let us" and is followed by the base form of the verb.
  • "Shall we...?" is another way to suggest, also followed by the base form of the verb.
